H0.text: The surfaces absorb energy from the air when they are rubbed together, which makes them warm.

H1.text: Friction changes the energy of motion to heat energy, which is why two surfaces get warm when they are rubbed together.

H2.text: Moving objects produce heat energy when they are rubbed together, causing the two surfaces to become warm.

H3.text: Energy is transferred between the two surfaces when they are rubbed together, causing them to warm.

A4.text: Thus, a force is required to move the back of the contact, and frictional heat is released at the front.

A5.text: some mechanical energy is transformed to heat, the free energy of structural changes, and other types of dissipation.
